Do Rising US Interest Rates Offer Opportunities in EM?


Emerging Markets Investment Grade Yields



As of 26 October 2023
Sovereign: JPM EMBI Global Diversified IG; Corporate: JPM CEMBI Broad Diversified IG
Source: Lazard, JP Morgan


Rising US interest rates--and soaring Treasury yields--have done their part to rattle global economics. As the environment settles, we expect growth differentials to shift, creating a more positive backdrop for emerging markets debt and interesting investment opportunities for the asset class across the capital structure.


•  Outlook on Emerging Markets

•  Outlook on Europe

•  Outlook on Japan

•  Outlook on the United Kingdom

One Column Content, Shift Right Modules
 

• What's Trending


One chart you need to see


Is Manufacturing Shifting from China to India?


While increased tariffs are causing many companies to navigate away from China and toward India, we believe China will likely remain an important manufacturing destination for the foreseeable future. Operating in the country is indeed becoming more difficult for foreign investorsbut it continues to have competitive infrastructure, an effective labor force, and long-standing relationships with foreign companies that would be challenging and costly to replace.

In praise of small language models


The global outlook has brightened in 2024 despite some disappointing news along the way. Ronald Temple, Chief Market Strategist, analyzes the forces that stand to impact global markets as the second half of 2024 unfolds, including the results of a razor's-edge US election, China's ongoing housing challenges, and potential Eurozone policy easing.

In praise of small language models


Large language models (LLMs) are progressing at breakneck speed, captivating investors and sweeping through markets. However, their tendency to hallucinate and their inherent opacity limit their utility for investment decisions. Small language models (SLMs), in contrast, offer reliability and interpretability. These qualities make SLMs especially well-suited for answering highly specific questions, as this paper demonstrates using a case study on China's housing market slowdown.

The MSCI Emerging Markets Index consists of emerging markets country indices including: Brazil, Chile, China, Colombia, Czech Republic, Egypt, Greece, Hungary, India, Indonesia, Korea, Malaysia, Mexico, Peru, Philippines, Poland, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, South Africa, Taiwan, Thailand, Turkey, and United Arab Emirates. The index is unmanaged and has no fees. One cannot invest directly in an index.
